title: Graviational Waves from Feynman Diagrams
text:
This is a Quarto book. I am going to try and hyperlink it as much as possible
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
The detection of gravitational waves by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) and Virgo collaborations in 2016 (2016) has sparked a new era of gravitational wave astronomy. The first detections were of Binary Black Hole (BBH) mergers. More recently, Binary Neutron Star (BNS) mergers (2017) as well as Neutron Star (NS)-Black Hole (BH) mergers have been detected (2021). Future detectors will further increase sensitivity and will be able to detect a wide range of astrophysical sources. Studying these gravitational waves signals gives us a very powerful new window into the universe. It allows us to study the properties of neutron stars and black holes, and the physics of compact object mergers, but also gives us a powerful testing apparatus for general relativity.

LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration, B. P. Abbott, R. Abbott, T. D. Abbott, M. R. Abernathy, F. Acernese, K. Ackley, et al. 2016. “Observation of Gravitational Waves from a Binary Black Hole Merger.” Physical Review Letters 116 (6): 061102. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.116.061102.

LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration, B. P. Abbott, R. Abbott, T. D. Abbott, F. Acernese, K. Ackley, C. Adams, et al. 2017. “GW170817: Observation of Gravitational Waves from a Binary Neutron Star Inspiral.” Physical Review Letters 119 (16): 161101. https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.119.161101.

Abbott, R., T. D. Abbott, S. Abraham, F. Acernese, K. Ackley, A. Adams, C. Adams, et al. 2021. “Observation of Gravitational Waves from Two Neutron Star.” The Astrophysical Journal Letters 915 (1): L5. https://doi.org/10.3847/2041-8213/ac082e.
To detect these faint signals LIGO and Virgo, have been made to be extraordinarily precise instruments. Thus, they demand correspondingly precise theoretical predictions and models. This is not just for comparison’s sake, but for detection as well. These faint signals are often buried in the noise of the detector. To counteract this experimental physicists make use of a matched filtering approach, where they try to match the signal to a template. The template is a model of the signal ideally provided by theoretical physicists based on physical theories. The more precise the template, the higher the signal-to-noise ratio, the more probable and precise the detection.
In this thesis we will explore the theoretical landscape surrounding the generation of these templates. We will focus on a nascent subfield where tools originally used for Quantum Field Theory (QFT) and particle physics are being applied to the study of gravitational waves. Specifically we are interested in the diagramatic objects that arise when frameing the two body problem in a similar way to particle collisions. We will explain where these tools shine in the broader context of waveform approaches such as Effective One-Body (EOB), Nonrelativistic General Relativity (NRGR), Post-Minkowski (PM) and Post-Newtonian (PN) approximations. We will also discuss the challenges that lie ahead in the field.

title: 2  Gravitational Wave Sources and Detection
text: First let us look at where and how gravitional waves are generated. We will look at how General Relativity (GR) predicts that graviational waves exist, and what conditions have to be met for them to become observable. We will also look at how we can detect them, and what we can learn from them.

title: 2  Gravitational Wave Sources and Detection
text:
2.1 Gravitational Waves
Einstein’s field equations,
\[
\boxed{\texttip{\texttip{R}{Ricci tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Ricci tensor component}-\frac{\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}}{2} \texttip{R}{Ricci scalar}+\texttip{\Lambda}{cosmological constant}\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}=-8 \pi \texttip{G}{gravitational constant}\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}}
\tag{2.1}\] or, equivalently, eliminating the Ricci scalar,
\[
\boxed{\texttip{\texttip{R}{Ricci tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Ricci tensor component}=-8 \pi G\left(\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}-\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace}\frac{\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}}{2}\right)+\texttip{\Lambda}{cosmological constant}\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}}
\tag{2.2}\]
with \(\texttip{\Lambda}{cosmological constant}=0\) admit wave solutions. We can see this by looking at these equations in the weak field approximation. Namely, we take the metric to be a Minkowskian background and a small perturbation
\[
    \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}= \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Minkoski metric components +---}+ \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component},
\tag{2.3}\]
with \(\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\) small. The Ricci tensor in this approximation is \[
\texttip{\texttip{R}{Ricci tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Ricci tensor component}= \frac{\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\rho}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}}{2}\left[ \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\rho\alpha}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu\nu}}{Partial derivative} + \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho\alpha}}{Partial derivative} - \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\mu\alpha}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho\nu}}{Partial derivative} - \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\nu\rho}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu\alpha}}{Partial derivative} \right] + \mathcal{O}(h^2)=\texttip{\texttip{R^{(1)}}{linearized Ricci tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant linearized Ricci tensor component}+ \mathcal{O}(h^2)
\tag{2.4}\]
To fix the ambiguity of choosing a coordinate system (‘gauge’), we impose the harmonic coordinate conditions, given by
\[
   \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant metric tensor component}\mathtip{\Gamma^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\alpha\beta}}{\text{Levi-Civita Connection: }\Gamma^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\alpha\beta}=
\frac{1}{2} \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}^{\mu \rho}}{contravariant metric tensor component}
\Big[
    \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \mu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha}}{Partial derivative}
    +\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \alpha}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}
    -\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\alpha \mu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative} \Big]
} =0
\]
Demanding the vanishing of the affine connection. Now we can impose the weak field approximation on the harmonic coordinate conditions (2.3), and we get pluggin in the affine connection in the weak field approximation 11 The affine connection is given by
\[\mathtip{\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\mu\nu}}{\text{Levi-Civita Connection: }\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\mu\nu}=
\frac{1}{2} \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}^{\alpha \rho}}{contravariant metric tensor component}
\Big[
    \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \alpha}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}
    +\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \mu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha}}{Partial derivative}
    -\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\mu \alpha}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative} \Big]
}=
\frac{1}{2} \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}^{\alpha \rho}}{contravariant metric tensor component}
\Big[
\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \nu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}
+ \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \mu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\nu}}{Partial derivative}
- \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative} \Big]
\] and in the weak approximation 2.3 we have \[\mathtip{\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\mu\nu}}{\text{Levi-Civita Connection: }\Gamma^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\mu\nu}=
\frac{1}{2} \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}^{\alpha \rho}}{contravariant metric tensor component}
\Big[
    \texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \alpha}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}
    +\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\rho \mu}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha}}{Partial derivative}
    -\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{\mu \alpha}}{covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative} \Big]
} \approx \frac{1}{2} \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha \rho}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}
\Big[
\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\rho \nu}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}
+ \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\rho \mu}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\nu}}{Partial derivative}
- \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative} \Big]\]
\[
\begin{split}
    (\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}+\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}^{\alpha\beta}}{weak contravariant metric tensor component})\frac{1}{2}(\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\mu\rho}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}+\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}^{\mu\rho}}{weak contravariant metric tensor component})\left[\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\rho}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\beta}}{Partial derivative}+\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\beta\rho}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha}}{Partial derivative}-\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\beta}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative}\right] &= 0 \\
    \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\mu\rho}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\left[2\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\rho}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\beta}}{Partial derivative}-\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\beta}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative}\right]+ \mathcal{O}(h^2)&= 0 \\
    \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\rho}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\beta}}{Partial derivative} &= \frac{1}{2}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\beta}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\rho}}{Partial derivative}\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---} + \mathcal{O}(h^2).
\end{split}
\] Thus \[
    \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\mu}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\nu\beta}}{Partial derivative} \approx \frac{1}{2}\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\beta}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu\nu}}{Partial derivative},
\] and \[
    \texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\beta\nu}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu\alpha}}{Partial derivative} \approx \frac{1}{2}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{\alpha\beta}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu\nu}}{Partial derivative}.
\] With these two relations the expression for the linearized Ricci tensor 2.4 simplifies to \[
    \texttip{\texttip{R^{(1)}}{linearized Ricci tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant linearized Ricci tensor component}= \frac{1}{2}\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\alpha\beta}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha\beta}}{Partial derivative} = \frac{1}{2}\Box_{SR} \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}.
\] For a system of harmonic coordinates, Einstein’s linearized equations become
\[
\begin{aligned}
    \square_{SR} \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}&= -16\pi \texttip{G}{gravitational constant}\overbracket{(\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}-\frac{\texttip{\texttip{g}{metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant metric tensor component}}{2}\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace})}^{S_{\mu \nu}}  \\
    h^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\mu}\texttip{{}_{,\alpha}}{Partial derivative}&=\frac{1}{2}h^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\alpha}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{2.5}\]
Where raising and lowering indices has been done with the Minkowski metric. We can now see what sort of solutions come out of these equations.
The first equation in 2.5 can be solved in a similar way to electrodynamics in the lorenz gauge. If we define the following retarded Green’s function \[
    \texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function} = -2\pi\,\texttip{\delta\left((x-x^\prime)^2\right)}{Dirac delta function}\texttip{\Theta\left(x^0>x^{\prime 0}\right)}{Heaviside step function},
\] which satisfies
\[
    \Box_x\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function} = \texttip{\delta\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{Dirac delta function}.
\]
Then, the solution to
\[
\Box_{SR} \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}=  -16 \pi \texttip{G}{gravitational constant}S_{\mu\nu}
\tag{2.6}\]
is given by:\(\mathrm{d}\)
\[
    \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}(x) = 8G\int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\,\,\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function}S_{\mu\nu}(x^\prime),
\tag{2.7}\]
since when we plug in 2.7 into 2.6 \[
    \Box_x\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}= 8G\int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\,\,\big(\underbrace{\Box_x\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function}}_{=-2\pi\,\delta(x-x^\prime)}\big) S_{\mu\nu}(x^\prime) = -16\pi GS_{\mu\nu}(x).
\] Performing the \(x^{\prime0}\) integration in 2.7, we have \[
\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}(x) = 8G\int\,\mathrm{d}^{3}x^\prime\,\,S_{\mu\nu}(\vec{x}^{\,\prime},t)\,\mathrm{d}^{}t^\prime\,\frac{\delta(t\prime-(t-|x-\vec{x}^{\,\prime}|))}{2|x-\vec{x}^{\,\prime}|}
\]
\[
\texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{weak covariant metric tensor component}(\vec{x},t) = 4G\int\,\mathrm{d}^{3}x\,\,\frac{S_{\mu\nu}(\vec{x}^{\,\prime},t-|\vec{x}-\vec{x}^{\,\prime}|)}{|\vec{x}-\vec{x}^{\,\prime}|}.
\tag{2.8}\]
The retarded solution above satisfies the harmonic coordinate condition of 2.5. Indeed, we have
\[
    \texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}\texttip{{}_{;\mu}}{Covariant derivative}=0\ \Rightarrow\ \texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}+\underbracket{\Gamma\,\Gamma\,}_{\mathclap{\mathrm{non-linear}}}=0\ \Rightarrow\ \texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}=0,
\]
ignoring non-linearities. Then,
\[
    S^{\mu\nu}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative} = \partial_\mu\left(\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}_{{\mu\nu}}}{covariant Stress-Energy tensor component}-\frac{\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\mu\nu}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}}{2}\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace}\right) = -\frac{\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\mu\nu}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---}}{2}\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}.
\]
Also
\[
    S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\mu} = \texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\mu}{}_{\mu}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace} -\frac{\delta^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\mu}}{2}\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace}= -\texttip{\texttip{T}{Stress-Energy tensor, or energy-momentum tensor}^{\alpha}{}_{\alpha}}{Stress-Energy tensor trace}.
\]
Thus
\[
\begin{split}
    S^{\mu\nu}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative} &= \frac{1}{2}S^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\alpha}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative}\texttip{\texttip{\eta}{Minkoski metric tensor +---}^{\mu\nu}}{contravariant Minkoski metric components +---} \\
    S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative} &= \frac{1}{2}S^{\alpha}_{\phantom{\alpha}\alpha}\texttip{{}_{,\nu}}{Partial derivative}.
\end{split}
\]
Then
\[
\begin{split}
    \texttip{\texttip{h}{weak metric tensor}_\mu{}^\nu}{weak mixed metric tensor component}\texttip{{}_{,\mu}}{Partial derivative} &= 8\texttip{G}{gravitational constant}\frac{\partial}{\partial x^\mu} \int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\, \texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function} S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu} (x^\prime) \\
&= 8\texttip{G}{gravitational constant}\int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\,\,\frac{\partial\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function}}{\partial x^\mu} S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu}(x^\prime) \\
    &= -8\texttip{G}{gravitational constant}\int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\,\frac{\partial\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function}}{\partial x^{\prime\mu}}S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu}(x^\prime) \\
    &= \underbrace{8G\texttip{\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{ret}}\left(x-x^\prime\right)}{ret Green's function}\delta^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu}(x^\prime)}_{=0\ \mathrm{for}\ x=x^\prime} + 8G\int\,\mathrm{d}^{4}x^\prime\,\,G_{\mathrm{ret}}S^{\mu}_{\phantom{\mu}\nu}(x^\prime)\texttip{{}_{,{\prime\mu}}}{Partial derivative} \\
\end{split}
\]
